section.name: s23C
section.heading: Entry into Central Military Dock Inner and Outer Areas

subsection.content: A vessel must not enter the Central Military Dock Inner Area except with the permission of the Director.
Before giving permission under paragraph (1), the Director must obtain the consent of the Hong Kong Garrison.
A vessel must not enter the Central Military Dock Outer Area except with the permission of the Director.

Even if a vessel is permitted to enter the Central Military Dock Inner Area under paragraph (1) or the Central Military Dock Outer Area under paragraph (3), it must not stay, anchor, moor or berth in the Area, unless otherwise specified in the permission.

Paragraph (3) does not apply to a vessel that has an overall length not exceeding 60 metres if it only enters the Central Military Dock Outer Area for the purpose of passing through the Area directly without staying, anchoring, mooring or berthing in the Area.

subsection.leadIn: If this regulation is contravened without reasonable excuse—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a vessel not being towed—the master of the vessel commits an offence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a vessel being towed—the master of the vessel and the masters of the tugs or other vessels towing the vessel commit an offence,

subsection.continued: and is, or each of them is, as the case may be, liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: In this regulation—
subsection.def: Central Military Dock Inner Area (中區軍用碼頭內圍區域) means the area specified in paragraph 34 of the Fifth Schedule;
Central Military Dock Outer Area (中區軍用碼頭外圍區域) means the area specified in paragraph 35 of the Fifth Schedule.

section.name: s24
section.heading: Navigation near the Ngong Shuen Chau Naval Basin

subsection.content: Except with the permission of the Hong Kong Garrison, no vessel shall enter or navigate within the Ngong Shuen Chau Naval Basin area specified in paragraph 17 of the Fifth Schedule. (L.N. 140 of 2000; 24 of 2005 s. 47)

subsection.leadIn: If without reasonable excuse this regulation is contravened—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a vessel not being towed, the master of the vessel commits an offence; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a vessel being towed, the master of the vessel and the master of any other vessel towing the vessel commit an offence,

subsection.continued: and is or each of them is (as the case may be) liable to a fine at level 1. (24 of 2005 s. 47)

subsection.leadIn: Except with the written permission of the Director, no person shall be embarked or disembarked, and no cargo shall be loaded, unloaded or transhipped, onto or from a vessel at any place within the waters of Hong Kong other than in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a port; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a special anchorage.

subsection.content: If without reasonable excuse paragraph (1) is contravened, the master of the vessel commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 1 year. (E.R. 4 of 2023)
Except with the permission of the Director, no vessel shall conduct a seatrial within the waters of Hong Kong.
If without reasonable excuse paragraph (1) is contravened, the owner and the master of the vessel commit an offence and each of them is liable to a fine at level 3. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

A ship shall, while within the waters of Hong Kong, have on board at all times such number of crew as is, in the opinion of the Director, qualified and capable of carrying out all duties which may reasonably be required to ensure the safety of the ship having regard to the circumstances pertaining thereto.
If this regulation is contravened, the owner and the master of the ship commit an offence and each of them is liable to a fine at level 4. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

A master who is required to have port clearance in respect of his vessel under section 15 of the Ordinance and who intends to proceed to sea shall apply to the Director for a port clearance before his intended departure and shall state the time of departure.
The Director shall, unless he has reason to refuse port clearance, grant port clearance on application made under paragraph (1) and return the ship’s papers to the master.

Before a port clearance is granted under paragraph (2), the master shall, if required to do so by the Director, inform the Director of the nature of the intended voyage, the number of passengers (if any) and the general description of the cargo on board the vessel, and provide such other information as the Director may require.
A port clearance granted under paragraph (2) shall cease to be valid if the vessel does not proceed to sea within 72 hours after the grant of the port clearance. (L.N. 302 of 1991)

section.name: s28
section.heading: Failure to depart on obtaining port clearance

subsection.content: If a master after having obtained port clearance under regulation 27 does not proceed to sea within 72 hours thereafter, he shall report forthwith to the Director the reason for not proceeding to sea and shall, if so required by the Director, deposit the ship’s papers with the Director. (L.N. 302 of 1991)
Any master who without reasonable excuse contravenes this regulation commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

Where a dead ship is expected to arrive in the waters of Hong Kong, the owner or his agent or the master thereof shall notify the Director of such expected arrival not less than 24 hours before the arrival of the dead ship, or, if that is not practicable, as early as practicable before the arrival of the dead ship.
Subject to paragraph (5), the owner or his agent or the master of a ship shall without delay notify the Director if the ship becomes a dead ship after its arrival within the waters of Hong Kong.

Subject to paragraph (5), the owner or his agent or the master of a dead ship which is within the waters of Hong Kong shall without delay notify the Director after the dead ship ceases to be a dead ship.

A notification required to be given to the Director under this regulation shall initially be given over a telephone or by means of a radio or radiotelephone transmission and shall then be confirmed in writing by the owner, agent or master within 24 hours after such initial notification.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Paragraph (2) shall not apply where permission to carry out maintenance or repair work is obtained under section 18(3) of the Ordinance.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Paragraphs (2) and (3) shall not apply to any dead ship to which section 18(2) and (3) of the Ordinance does not apply.

subsection.content: Any owner, agent or master who without reasonable excuse contravenes this regulation commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (E.R. 4 of 2023)
An owner, agent or master shall give to the Director such information as the Director may require in respect of a dead ship or a ship which is to become a dead ship.
The information which the Director may require under paragraph (1) shall be such as he may reasonably require for the exercise of his powers in relation to the proper control of dead ships.

Any information required under paragraph (1) which is given over a telephone or by means of a radio or radiotelephone transmission shall, if so required by the Director, be given in writing by the owner, agent or master within 24 hours after such requirement.

Where a vessel, which to the knowledge of the owner or his agent or the master thereof will become a laid-up vessel whilst within the waters of Hong Kong, is expected to arrive in such waters, the owner, agent or master shall notify the Director of such expected arrival not less than 24 hours before the arrival of the vessel, or, if that is not practicable, as early as practicable before the arrival of the vessel.
The owner or his agent or the master of a vessel shall without delay notify the Director if the vessel becomes a laid-up vessel after its arrival within the waters of Hong Kong.
The owner or his agent or the master of a laid-up vessel which is within the waters of Hong Kong shall without delay notify the Director after the laid-up vessel ceases to be a laid-up vessel.

A notification required to be given to the Director under this regulation shall initially be given over a telephone or by means of a radio or radiotelephone transmission and shall then be confirmed in writing by the owner, agent or master within 24 hours after such initial notification.
Any owner, agent or master who without reasonable excuse contravenes this regulation commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (E.R. 4 of 2023)
An owner, agent or master shall give to the Director such information as the Director may require in respect of a laid-up vessel or a vessel which is to become a laid-up vessel.
The information which the Director may require under paragraph (1) shall be such as he may reasonably require for the exercise of his powers in relation to the proper control of laid-up vessels.

Any information required under paragraph (1) which is given over a telephone or by means of a radio or radiotelephone transmission shall, if so required by the Director, be given in writing by the owner, agent or master within 24 hours after such requirement.

The owner, agent or master of a vessel which is a tanker shall, not less than 24 hours before the intended entry of that vessel into the waters of Hong Kong, inform the Director to that effect by notification and provide the information specified in the Seventeenth Schedule.
Any owner, agent or master who without reasonable excuse contravenes this regulation commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

subsection.leadIn: Every vessel shall— (43 of 1999 s. 91)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: when entering the waters of Hong Kong between sunrise and sunset, hoist her— (L.N. 408 of 1994)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: national colours;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: house flag (if any); and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: signal letters;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: when entering and leaving any port, hoist her national colours;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: when underway in any port between sunrise and sunset, keep her identification flags hoisted and also fly, well clear of the identification flags, the appropriate berthing signal, if any, specified in the Eighth Schedule;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: when underway in the waters of Hong Kong between sunset and sunrise, identify herself, if so required by any vessel which makes the international code signal “K”;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: hoist her signal letters not less than 30 minutes before leaving a berth or anchorage between sunrise and sunset;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: hoist a Blue Peter not less than 18 hours before the intended time of proceeding to sea.

subsection.content: If without reasonable excuse paragraph (1) is contravened, the master of the vessel commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

section.name: s34
section.heading: Display of flags “S” over the code pennant

subsection.content: The master of a vessel which has been boarded by an authorized officer pursuant to section 59 of the Ordinance shall if required by such authorized officer hoist the international code flags “S” over the answering pennant.

subsection.leadIn: Where the international code flags “S” over the answering pennant are hoisted under paragraph (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: no person shall board or leave the vessel; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: no other vessel shall approach within 30 metres of the vessel,

subsection.continued: without the permission of the authorized officer.

subsection.content: Any master who fails to comply with a requirement under paragraph (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (E.R. 4 of 2023)
Any person who contravenes paragraph (2)(a), or the master of any vessel which contravenes paragraph (2)(b), commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

subsection.leadIn: A police launch shall, for the purposes of regulation 20, exhibit the following signal—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: between sunrise and sunset, a blue flag with one white and two red diagonal stripes; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: between sunset and sunrise, a blue light.

subsection.content: If any vessel exhibits without authority any signal specified in paragraph (1), the master of the vessel commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

section.name: s36
section.heading: Signals for fire or police assistance
section.leadIn: Where fire services assistance or police assistance is required on a vessel—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: between sunrise and sunset, the international code signal “CB3” shall be hoisted and, in the case of fire, that signal may be supplemented by the international code signal “CB6” “I am on fire”;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: between sunset and sunrise, 3 all-round lights in a vertical line, the highest and the lowest lights white and the middle red, shall be exhibited and that signal may be supplemented by a “flare up” every minute in the case of fire or “blue lights” in the case of riot or disturbance, and, in either case, a continuous sounding with any fog signal apparatus may, in addition, be adopted.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the Dangerous Goods (Shipping) Regulation 2012 (Cap. 295 sub. leg. F), a vessel on which explosives are being handled must— (29 of 2021 s. 24)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: between sunrise and sunset, fly the international code signal “B” at the fore masthead; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: between sunset and sunrise, exhibit an all-round red light at a height of not less than 6 metres above the uppermost deck, and such light must be of such intensity as to be visible in clear atmosphere on a dark night at a distance of at least one nautical mile.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the Dangerous Goods (Shipping) Regulation 2012 (Cap. 295 sub. leg. F), a vessel on which petroleum having a flash point not exceeding 60o Celsius is being handled must— (29 of 2021 s. 24)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: between sunrise and sunset, fly a red flag of not less than one metre square with a white circular centre 150 millimetres in diameter at the fore masthead and must also fly the international code signal “S.U.7.”; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: between sunset and sunrise, exhibit an all-round red light at a height of not less than 6 metres above the uppermost deck, and such light must be of such intensity as to be visible in clear atmosphere on a dark night at a distance of at least one nautical mile.

subsection.content: If this regulation is contravened, the master of the vessel commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.def: For the purpose of this regulation, handle (處理) includes all operations connected with the loading, unloading, discharging, stacking, stowing or restowing.

subsection.content: A vessel which is being towed by tugs in the waters of Hong Kong shall, where radiotelephone equipment is not available for use, use the towing signals specified in the Ninth Schedule to convey directions to the tugs.
If without reasonable excuse this regulation is contravened, the master of the vessel commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

subsection.leadIn: Every junk, which is not mechanically propelled, when underway in the waters of Hong Kong at any time between sunset and sunrise shall exhibit—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the lights prescribed for sailing vessels underway in the collision regulations; or (57 of 1990 s. 7)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: 2 all-round white lights of such intensity as to be visible in clear atmosphere on a dark night at a distance of at least one nautical mile, one of which shall be placed at the fore masthead and the other at the stern at a height above the uppermost continuous deck of not less than 2 metres.

subsection.content: If this regulation is contravened, the master of the junk commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

An owner or occupier of a pier, whether completed or under construction, shall, unless exempted in writing by the Director, at all times between sunset and sunrise cause a red light to be exhibited within 2 metres of the outer end of the pier and at a height above it of not less than 3 metres nor more than 6 metres, and such red light shall be of such intensity and so constructed as to be visible from seaward in clear atmosphere on a dark night at a distance of at least one nautical mile.
Any owner or occupier of a pier who contravenes paragraph (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

part.name: P5
part.heading: Anchoring, Mooring and Berthing of Vessels

subsection.leadIn: Subject to paragraph (2), a vessel shall not anchor at any place in a port other than at a place—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: set aside by the Director for the anchorage of that particular type, class or description of vessel or for a particular purpose; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specified by the Director in any particular case.

subsection.leadIn: No vessel shall anchor or lie—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: within any principal fairway;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the direct approaches to the Lei Yue Mun Pass or Sulphur Channel;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in a position which obstructs the approaches or entrances to any principal fairway, typhoon shelter or pier;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in a position which gives a foul berth to any other vessel made fast to a mooring, pier or dock premises;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: except with the permission of the Director, within 500 metres of any place or vessel designated as a Government Explosives Depot under section 13A of the Dangerous Goods Ordinance (Cap. 295);

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: except with the permission of the Director, at any place at which anchoring or lying is prohibited by notice posted under any regulation made in relation to the prohibition under section 89 of the Merchant Shipping (Local Vessels) Ordinance (Cap. 548); (24 of 2005 s. 48)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: if the vessel exceeds an overall length of 100 metres, within the Yau Ma Tei Anchorage except with the permission of the Director;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: in an immigration anchorage except for the purpose of compliance with the Immigration Ordinance (Cap. 115);

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: in a quarantine anchorage except for the purpose of compliance with the Prevention and Control of Disease Ordinance (Cap. 599); (L.N. 386 of 1993; 14 of 2008 s. 18)

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: in a dangerous goods anchorage except for the purpose of compliance with the Dangerous Goods Ordinance (Cap. 295); and

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: in a naval anchorage except with the permission of the Hong Kong Garrison. (24 of 2005 s. 48)

subsection.content: If without reasonable excuse this regulation is contravened, the master of the vessel commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

section.name: s41A
section.heading: Anchoring of vessels within prohibited anchorage area

subsection.content: Except with the permission of the Director, a vessel shall not anchor within the prohibited anchorage area specified in the Nineteenth Schedule.

subsection.leadIn: Paragraph (1) does not apply to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a vessel used by the Government in connection with the performance of official duties;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a vessel used by the Chinese People’s Liberation Army in connection with the performance of official duties; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a privately owned vessel that is under contract with the Government and that is used in connection with the performance of the Government’s official duties.

subsection.content: If without reasonable excuse this regulation is contravened, the master of the vessel commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.
No vessel shall moor to a buoy unless the buoy is one laid for mooring purposes.
If without reasonable excuse this regulation is contravened, the master of the vessel commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 1. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

section.name: s43
section.heading: Use of Government buoys and moorings

subsection.content: Except with the permission of the Director, no vessel shall moor to a Government mooring buoy.
A vessel shall be secured to a Government mooring buoy by her anchor cable.

subsection.leadIn: A vessel which is moored to a Government mooring buoy shall not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: swing ship for compass adjustment; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: test main propulsion machinery.

subsection.content: When a tropical cyclone warning signal is announced by the Hong Kong Observatory every vessel (other than a dead ship) which is moored to a Government mooring buoy shall clear anchor and cables and prepare the main propulsion machinery to full power conditions and such vessel shall, if so directed by the Director, leave the mooring buoy. (L.N. 408 of 1994; L.N. 362 of 1997)
If without reasonable excuse this regulation is contravened, the master of the vessel commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3. (E.R. 4 of 2023)
No vessel shall berth at any berth other than at the berth allocated to the vessel by the Director. (43 of 1999 s. 91)

subsection.leadIn: A vessel which is berthed shall not leave the berth unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: directed to do so by the Director; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: permission to do so is obtained from the Director.

subsection.content: If without reasonable excuse this regulation is contravened, the master of the vessel commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3 to a further fine of $1,000 for every hour or part of an hour during which the vessel remains in a berth in contravention of this regulation after the master thereof has been directed by the Director to move from such berth. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

Save as provided in this regulation or as permitted by the Director, no vessel shall lie alongside any other vessel which is berthed anywhere in a port, other than in a typhoon shelter specified in the Merchant Shipping (Local Vessels) (Typhoon Shelters) Regulation (Cap. 548 sub. leg. E). (24 of 2005 s. 55)
A bunkering vessel may lie alongside another vessel for the purpose of bunkering. (27 of 2024 s. 8)
If without reasonable excuse this regulation is contravened, the master of the vessel commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

Except with the permission of the Director, no vessel shall lie alongside a Government pier for any purpose other than to enable passengers to embark or disembark (with their luggage, if any) and for any time longer than is reasonably necessary for such embarking or disembarking.
Except with the permission of the Director, no vessel exceeding 35 metres in length shall go alongside any Government pier.
If without reasonable excuse this regulation is contravened, the master of the vessel commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 1. (E.R. 4 of 2023)
No vessel shall make fast to any part of a Government pier or Hong Kong Garrison pier except to the recognized mooring bollards and rings provided thereon as moorings. (2 of 2012 s. 3)
No vessel shall lie alongside any pier unless the pier is designed and constructed for the purpose.
If without reasonable excuse this regulation is contravened, the master of the vessel commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 1. (E.R. 4 of 2023)
No person shall lay a private mooring anywhere in the waters of Hong Kong except in the place specified in the permission granted under section 6 of the Ordinance.

A private mooring laid under paragraph (1) shall not be used by any vessel not owned by or under the control of the owner of the private mooring except with the consent of the owner of the private mooring or by direction of the Director.
Subject to paragraph (4), the fee prescribed in the Thirteenth Schedule shall be paid for the keeping of a private mooring. (L.N. 127 of 1985)
No fee shall be payable in respect of a private mooring if the Director is satisfied that the mooring is used exclusively for warping purposes.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to paragraph (5A), if the owner of a private mooring sells or otherwise transfers the private mooring—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he and the purchaser or transferee shall notify the Director in a form specified by the Director of the name and address of the new owner and shall give such other information as the Director may require; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the purchaser or transferee shall pay the transfer of ownership fee prescribed in the Thirteenth Schedule,

subsection.continued: in each case within 14 days after the date of the sale or transfer. (L.N. 127 of 1985)

subsection.name: 5A
subsection.content: Paragraph (5) shall not apply to the sale or transfer of a private mooring by the Director. (L.N. 127 of 1985)

A private mooring and the chains, shackles and other accessories of the mooring shall be of such nature and construction as the Director may direct and the owner of the mooring shall keep and maintain the mooring and its accessories in the approved position and in good condition.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may inspect a private mooring and its accessories and may require the owner of the private mooring—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to carry out any repairs to the mooring or its accessories;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to re-lay or renew the mooring; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to remove the mooring.

subsection.leadIn: Any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: contravenes paragraph (1), (5)(a) or (6); or (L.N. 127 of 1985)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: fails to comply with any direction or requirement under paragraph (6) or (7),

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

subsection.content: If any vessel uses any private mooring in contravention of paragraph (2), the owner or master of the vessel commits an offence and is liable to a fine of $300 for each day or part of a day during which the mooring is so used.

subsection.leadIn: Where in respect of a private mooring—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the prescribed fee is not paid under paragraph (3) or (5)(b); or (L.N. 127 of 1985)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an offence is committed under paragraph (8),

subsection.continued: the Director may, without prejudice to the liability of the owner of the private mooring for the fee or the penalty, as the case may be, remove the private mooring and its accessories or sell the mooring and its accessories.

subsection.content: Subject to paragraph (2), the port dues and fees prescribed in the Thirteenth Schedule shall be paid in respect of every vessel which enters the waters of Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: No port dues shall be payable under paragraph (1) in respect of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a vessel underway in transit through the waters of Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a vessel sheltering in the waters of Hong Kong from stress of weather; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a vessel entering the waters of Hong Kong solely for the purpose of landing a sick or injured person.

subsection.content: If the period, or aggregate period, for which a vessel lies at anchor in the waters of Hong Kong on an occasion of entry to those waters exceeds 12 hours, the anchorage dues prescribed in the Thirteenth Schedule shall be paid in respect of the vessel for the time in excess. (L.N. 201 of 2005)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of paragraph (1), a vessel does not lie at anchor in the waters of Hong Kong if it is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at anchor in a naval anchorage;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: secured to a mooring or pier;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: secured alongside a shipyard or at a slipway or dry dock; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: secured alongside a vessel which is secured alongside a shipyard. (L.N. 201 of 2005)

subsection.leadIn: No anchorage dues shall be payable under paragraph (1) in respect of any vessel—

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: sheltering in the waters of Hong Kong from stress of weather; or (L.N. 201 of 2005)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: equipped to the Director’s satisfaction as a cable ship or salvage vessel and which is based on Hong Kong. (L.N. 201 of 2005)

section.name: s51
section.heading: Mooring buoy dues
section.content: The mooring buoy dues prescribed in the Thirteenth Schedule shall be paid in respect of every Government mooring buoy which is occupied by or reserved for a vessel.

section.name: s52
section.heading: Fees
section.content: The fees prescribed in the Thirteenth Schedule shall be payable for certificates, permits and other services specified in that Schedule.

section.name: s53
section.heading: Tonnage of vessels liable to pay port dues or fees

subsection.content: For the purpose of calculating any port dues or fees payable under the Ordinance which are based on the tonnage of a vessel, the Director may require the owner or his agent or the master of the vessel to produce for inspection the register of the vessel.

Where the owner, agent or master fails to comply with any requirement under paragraph (1) or to satisfy the Director as to the true tonnage of a vessel, the Director may cause the vessel to be measured, and such measurement shall be deemed to be the true tonnage of the vessel for the purpose of calculating the port dues or fees.

Any expenses incurred by the Director in measuring a vessel under paragraph (2) shall be recoverable from the owner or his agent or the master of the vessel in the same manner as port dues payable under the Ordinance are recoverable.

An owner or master of a vessel who refuses to allow his vessel to be measured under paragraph (2) or obstructs any person carrying out such measurement shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to a fine at level 2. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

section.name: s54
section.heading: Issue and production of receipt for port dues and fees

subsection.content: The Director shall issue a receipt for any port dues or fees paid under the Ordinance.

The Director may require the production for inspection of any receipt issued under paragraph (1) and may refuse to grant port clearance in respect of a vessel, in respect of which any dues or fees are payable, until such receipt is produced.

section.name: s55
section.heading: Tables of port dues and fees
section.content: The Director shall cause to be posted at such place as he may determine tables of all port dues and fees prescribed under the Ordinance.

section.name: s55A
section.heading: Interpretation of Part VIA
section.content: In this Part, typhoon shelter (避風塘) means a typhoon shelter specified in the Merchant Shipping (Local Vessels) (Typhoon Shelters) Regulation (Cap. 548 sub. leg. E).

section.name: s55B
section.heading: Permit to enter and remain in typhoon shelters

subsection.content: The Director may, subject to such conditions as he thinks fit, grant a permit in writing permitting any vessel to enter and remain in a typhoon shelter specified in the permit.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may, add to, delete or vary the conditions of a permit if he is satisfied that the vessel is so situated or in such a condition that it—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: endangers the safety of persons, other vessels or property; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: poses a hazard to the environment.

section.name: s55C
section.heading: Use of typhoon shelters
section.content: Except with the permission of the Director granted under regulation 55B(1), no vessel shall enter or remain in a typhoon shelter.

section.name: s55D
section.heading: Power to remove vessels unlawfully in typhoon shelters

subsection.content: If any vessel enters or remains in a typhoon shelter in contravention of regulation 55C, the Director may, subject to paragraphs (2) and (3), take possession of the vessel and remove it from the typhoon shelter or move it from the position in which it is lying.

Subject to paragraph (3), the Director shall give to the owner or his agent or master of a vessel not less than 7 days’ notice in writing of any proposed exercise of his power under paragraph (1) and the notice shall state the reason therefor.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may exercise his power under paragraph (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at any time after notice of the proposed exercise of power is given under paragraph (2), notwithstanding that the period of notice has not expired, if a strong monsoon signal or tropical cyclone warning signal is issued by the Hong Kong Observatory; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: without giving notice, if the owner or his agent or master of the vessel cannot be found or if, in the opinion of the Director, the vessel is abandoned.

subsection.content: If any person on board a vessel obstructs the Director in the exercise of his power under paragraph (1), the Director may evict such person from the vessel.
The Director may use such force as may be reasonably necessary for the exercise of his power under paragraph (1) or for the purposes of paragraph (4).

section.name: s55E
section.heading: Production of permit
section.leadIn: The Director may require the owner or his agent or master of a vessel to produce any permit granted under regulation 55B in respect of the vessel—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for inspection for the purpose of ensuring compliance with these regulations; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for amendment of the conditions subject to which the permit is granted.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to paragraph (2), in the event of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a contravention of a condition of a permit granted under regulation 55B;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a contravention of regulation 55C; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a failure to comply with a requirement under regulation 55E,

subsection.continued: the owner, his agent and the master of the vessel commit an offence and each of them is liable to a fine at level 2.

subsection.content: In a charge for an offence under paragraph (1), it shall be a defence for the person charged to show that he had taken all practicable steps to prevent the commission of the offence.
Any person who obstructs the Director in the exercise of his power under regulation 55D(1) or (4) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

Where a permit granted under regulation 4(1) of the Shipping and Port Control (Typhoon Shelters) Regulations (Cap. 313 sub. leg. D) is in force immediately before the commencement* of this regulation in respect of a vessel, the permit shall have effect from such commencement as if it were a permit granted under regulation 55B, and the other provisions of this Part shall apply accordingly.

Where a permit that has effect by virtue of paragraph (1) has been granted in respect of a specified period, the permit shall remain in force for so much of the period as remains unexpired from the commencement of this regulation.

section.name: s56
section.heading: Discharge and storage of logs and timber

subsection.leadIn: Except with the written permission of the Director, no person shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: load or discharge on or from a vessel logs or other timber onto or from any waterfront or seawall within the boundaries of any port other than within the limits of a privately owned or leased waterfront or seawall;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: discharge logs or other timber from a vessel into the waters of Hong Kong other than in a timber storage pound;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: store logs or other timber in the waters of Hong Kong other than in a timber storage pound;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: tow logs, or permit them to lie afloat or rest on the sea bed, in the waters of Hong Kong other than in a timber storage pound; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: discharge logs or other timber (other than sawn timber) from one vessel to another in the waters of Hong Kong.

subsection.content: Any person who contravenes paragraph (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

The owner or his agent or master of a vessel from which it is intended to discharge logs or other timber (other than sawn timber) into any other vessel within the waters of Hong Kong shall give notice of such intention to the Director, in such form as the Director may specify, not less than 24 hours before the discharge commences.

subsection.leadIn: The owner, or the person in charge, of logs or log rafts which are being towed in the waters of Hong Kong shall exhibit—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: between sunrise and sunset, red flags not less than 600 millimetres square at each end of every log or log raft at a height of not less than 2 metres above sea level, and if any log or log raft exceeds 15 metres in length a third similar flag at the middle thereof;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: between sunset and sunrise, all-round white lights in place of the flags required under subparagraph (a), and such lights shall be of sufficient intensity so as to be visible in clear atmosphere on a dark night at a distance of at least one nautical mile.

subsection.content: Any person who contravenes paragraph (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

The Director may approve as a timber storage pound any area of the waters of Hong Kong in which logs and other timber may be stored, whether floating or submerged, and in granting such approval he may impose such conditions as he thinks fit.
Any person who fails to comply with any condition imposed under paragraph (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (E.R. 4 of 2023)
The owner of logs stored in the waters of Hong Kong shall mark every such log for the purpose of identifying the owner and shall notify the Director in writing of the identification mark used.
Any owner of logs who contravenes paragraph (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

section.name: s60
section.heading: Removal, etc. of logs and other objects

subsection.leadIn: The Director may give such directions as he thinks fit in respect of the removal, movement or securing of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a log or other timber which is stranded, floating or submerged in the waters of Hong Kong, other than in a timber storage pound;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other object which is stranded, floating or submerged in the waters of Hong Kong and which is a hazard to navigation.

subsection.content: A direction under paragraph (1) may be given to the owner or other person who claims that he is entitled to the possession of the log or other timber or object.

If any direction given under paragraph (1) is not complied with by the person to whom the direction is given, he commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

subsection.leadIn: The Director may seize and detain a log or other timber or object referred to in paragraph (1) if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a direction given under paragraph (1) is not complied with; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: after reasonable inquiry he is unable to ascertain the name and address of, or after reasonable attempts fails to contact, the owner or other person entitled to the possession of the log or other timber or object.

subsection.content: For the purposes of seizing a log or other timber or object under paragraph (4), the Director may take any action that is necessary to remove, move or secure the log or other timber or object.

subsection.leadIn: The Director shall publish in the Gazette and in one English language and one Chinese language newspaper circulating in Hong Kong a notice of a seizure effected under paragraph (4) and the notice shall specify—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: a description of the log or other timber or object and the place at which it was seized;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a reasonable period within which and the place at which a claim shall be submitted for the release of the log or other timber or object.

subsection.content: If a valid claim to a log or other timber or object seized under paragraph (4) is submitted at any time before a notice is published under paragraph (6) or within the period specified in a notice published under that paragraph, the Director shall, on payment to him of all expenses involved in the seizure and custody thereof, release the log or other timber or object to the claimant.

If the release of a log or other timber or object is not obtained in pursuance of paragraph (7), the Director may sell, or otherwise dispose of in such other manner as he thinks fit, the log or other timber or object, as the case may be, and in the case of sale the proceeds, after deducting all expenses payable under paragraph (7) and any reasonable expense incurred in the sale, shall be paid to the person making a valid claim thereto within 6 months after the date of sale or forfeited to the Government if not claimed within that period. (64 of 1999 s. 3)

section.name: s62
section.heading: Use of naked lights and oil

subsection.content: No naked light shall be used on board any vessel in the waters of Hong Kong.

No oil which gives off an inflammable vapour at less than 48.9o
Celsius shall be used to burn in lanterns on any vessel.
Any person who contravenes this regulation commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

Subject to paragraph (2), no person shall use a light on or from a vessel in the waters of Hong Kong in a manner that is likely to interfere with the safe operation of any other vessel or any aircraft.

subsection.leadIn: Paragraph (1) does not apply to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a public officer in the exercise of his powers or performance of his duty; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Chinese People’s Liberation Army. (2 of 2012 s. 3)

subsection.content: Any person who without reasonable excuse contravenes paragraph (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

section.name: s64
section.heading: Transport or disposal of things unlawfully obtained, etc.

subsection.content: Any person who for the purpose of preventing seizure or discovery of any cargo or other thing unlawfully obtained from or carried on a vessel wilfully lets fall or throws such cargo or other thing into the waters of Hong Kong commits an offence.

subsection.leadIn: Any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: conveys in any vessel; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any manner conveys away from a vessel, pier, seawall or waterfront,

subsection.continued: any cargo or other thing unlawfully obtained from a vessel in the waters of Hong Kong commits an offence.

subsection.content: Any person who commits an offence under this regulation is liable to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

subsection.leadIn: A police officer may take into custody any person who is contravening, or who he has reasonable grounds for believing has contravened, paragraph (1) or (2) and may seize and detain any vessel—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: out of which the cargo or other thing is let fall or thrown;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in which the cargo or other thing is conveyed; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in which such person is found.

subsection.leadIn: No person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall dredge for any purpose in any cable reserve;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shall without the permission of the Director sound a whistle, siren, bell, gong or foghorn on board any vessel in a port except as provided in the collision regulations or these regulations; (57 of 1990 s. 7)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: not being a public officer or a member of the Chinese People’s Liberation Army acting under Article 14 of the Law of the People’s Republic of China on the Garrisoning of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region in Schedule 2 to the Promulgation of National Laws (No. 2) 1997 (L.N. 386 of 1997), shall make fast to or cause to be made fast to a ship underway within the waters of Hong Kong any vessel except with the permission of the master of the ship. (2 of 2012 s. 3)

subsection.content: Any person who contravenes this regulation commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

section.name: s66
section.heading: Control over races, etc., in the waters of Hong Kong

subsection.leadIn: Except with the permission of the Director, no person shall hold or organize in or upon any part of the waters of Hong Kong any—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: race, regatta or similar event in which vessels of any type take part; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: swimming race or similar event,

subsection.continued: which interferes with, or is likely to interfere with, the navigation of vessels or the safety of any person in or upon such waters.

subsection.content: On the occasion of any race, regatta or similar event referred to in paragraph (1) in or upon any part of the waters of Hong Kong, the Director may prohibit or regulate all traffic upon or in the vicinity of such waters and may give to an organizer of, and persons taking part in, the race, regatta or similar event such directions as he thinks fit for the avoidance of accidents and the safety of persons.

Any person who contravenes paragraph (1) or fails to comply with any prohibition or regulation of traffic, or direction given, under paragraph (2) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 1. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

section.name: s66A
section.heading: Control over fireworks display in the waters of Hong Kong

subsection.content: On the occasion of any fireworks display held or organized in or upon any part of the waters of Hong Kong, the Director may prohibit or regulate all traffic upon or in the vicinity of such waters and may give to any person such directions as he thinks fit for the avoidance of accidents and the safety of persons.
Any person who fails to comply with any prohibition or regulation of traffic, or direction given, under paragraph (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 1.

section.name: s67
section.heading: Control over water-skiing and speed of vessels

subsection.leadIn: The Director may, by notice in the Gazette and in any other manner he thinks fit, prohibit within any area of the waters of Hong Kong any vessel from—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: towing any water ski, aquaplane or other similar object, or any person, or any person riding upon a water ski, aquaplane or other similar object. (L.N. 107 of 2000)

subsection.content: A person in charge of a vessel which is used for the purpose of towing any person, whether or not such person is riding upon a water ski, aquaplane or other similar object, shall be accompanied by another person not below 18 years of age who shall be responsible for communicating to the person in charge any mishap occurring to the person being towed.
Any person in charge of a vessel who contravenes a notice under paragraph (1), or paragraph (2), commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 1. (E.R. 4 of 2023)
No person shall fish by purse net, seine net, drift net, trawl, cage trap, hand line or long line in any prohibited fishing area specified in Part I of the Eleventh Schedule.

subsection.leadIn: No person shall in the waters of Hong Kong—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: erect or maintain a stake net; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: operate a beach seine net,

subsection.continued: except under, and in accordance with, a licence granted under paragraph (3).

subsection.leadIn: The Director may, on payment of the fee prescribed in the Thirteenth Schedule, grant to any person an annual licence, or renew an annual licence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the erection and maintenance of a stake net; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the operation of a beach seine net.

subsection.leadIn: A licensee shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: not transfer a licence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: not erect or maintain a stake net otherwise than at the place specified in the licence or within 200 metres of an existing stake net without the permission of the owner of that existing stake net;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: exhibit on a stake net in a conspicuous position a notice, supplied free of charge by the Director, showing the number of the licence of the stake net;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: exhibit on a stake net, between sunset and sunrise, a white light visible in all directions seaward, and such light shall be of such intensity as to be visible in clear atmosphere on a dark night at a distance of at least one nautical mile;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: remove at his expense a stake net that is not in use, and if he fails to do so the Director may remove it and recover the cost of removal from the licensee as a civil debt;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: comply with any conditions attached to a licence.

subsection.content: Any person who contravenes this regulation commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 1. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

subsection.leadIn: In this regulation, unless the context otherwise requires—
subsection.def: beach seine net (岸灘圍網) means a net not less than 30 metres in length by 1 metre in width, that is shot from a boat and hauled by both ends to the shore;

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an inshore net, which means a net attached to poles and worked by a windlass stationed on shore or in less than 6 metres of water;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an offshore net, which means a net attached to poles and worked by a windlass stationed in more than 6 metres of water;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a line of stakes and nets, which means a net or nets attached to a line of stakes driven into the foreshore or sea-bed.

subsection.content: No person shall within the waters of Hong Kong use bright light on any vessel for the purpose of fishing or attracting fish except in the areas specified in Part II of the Eleventh Schedule and in accordance with paragraphs (2) and (3).

A bright light shall be exhibited not less than 2 metres below any light exhibited in accordance with Rule 26(c) of the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea 1972 as defined and set out in the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Signals of Distress and Prevention of Collisions) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. N). (L.N. 302 of 1991)

A bright light shall be so constructed, shaded, installed and used that no light emitted therefrom shall be visible, whether directly or by reflection from any source other than sea surface, above a horizontal plane passing through the lowest edge of the light source. (L.N. 302 of 1991)
Any person who contravenes this regulation commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

section.name: s70
section.heading: Notification and control of marine works

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the provisions of any other enactment, no person shall commence any construction or reclamation works, dredging, boring, cable laying or any other type of works in the waters of Hong Kong, which interfere or are likely to interfere with the navigation of vessels or with port facilities, without giving the Director at least 14 days’ notice in writing of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the nature of the works;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date of their commencement;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the locality in which they will be carried out; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the estimated duration of the works.

subsection.content: The person in control of the works referred to in paragraph (1) shall, during the carrying out of the works, comply with such directions as the Director may give to ensure the safety of vessels navigating in the vicinity of the works.

subsection.leadIn: Any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: contravenes paragraph (1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: fails to comply with any direction given under paragraph (2),

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (E.R. 4 of 2023)

section.name: s71
section.heading: Form
section.content: The notice under section 77 of the Ordinance shall be in the form contained in the Twelfth Schedule.

subsection.content: The Director may by notice in the Gazette amend the Schedules other than the Twelfth and Thirteenth Schedules.

Where the master of an outbound vessel outside the waters of Hong Kong is to report to the vessel traffic centre he should use the VHF channel appropriate to the VHF sector which the vessel left.
